text: We pan across the city skyline, a beautiful sight -- over which we hear the CLACKING of computer keys.

A wall of glass offers a letter-boxed view of a sleek conference room. Amber sconces illuminate an enormous tab empty save for & YOUNG MAN at the far end - a lonely figu hunched over a laptop. Steadily tighten on JONATHAN MESSER (late 20s), trim buil not entirely at ease in a suit. Likeable features suggest gentle, intelligent demeanor. Grids of numbers from the laptop screen reflect off his glasses. Tired, he rubs his eyes, continues typing.

Briefcase in hand, Jonathan walks a vacant corridor of em cubicles. In a few offices lights are still on; the figur of YOUNG MEN AND WOMEN at work are blurred like photos ou focus behind the frosted-glass of closed doors.
Waiting for his train, Jonathan pauses at a news kiosk.
Do-you have tomorrow's Times yet? The grizzled OLD MAN behind the counter doesn't look up.
It is tomorrow. (CONTINUED)
Right. I forgot. The Old man grudgingly bends to cut the plastic on a fres stack of newspapers. As he does, Jonathan glances at nume porn magazines on display. Naked women smile back at him
Anything else?
Uh - no. No that's it, thanks.

Jonathan descends an above-ground subway stop. Neighborho streets are vacant, the clopping of his shoes the only so Jonathan turns a corner, heads for a humble duplex, the f floor marked by unlit neon: "FLEURS DE SOLANGE." He ascen the steps, his keys out --
Jonathan! The voice from nowhere startles him - he spins to find
standing in the doorway below, bundled in a ski jacket.
Solange, you're up so late?
So early, Jonathan. We open in one hour. (GRINS)
So tell me, you have been out with a lady friend, oui?
(SMILES)
Je suis desole, madame, mais no.
But why else does a young man come home at such an hour?
Just working late, that's all.
Every night working late, working late. (teasing him) Ah, you can't fool me. You are Mister Mischief maker - I know this! You come by (CONTINUED)
later and pick out something for your lady friend, oui?
Very modest. Furnishings are nice, but sparse. Jonathan h his suit jacket in a closet of empty hangers.

Not much decoration other than a dated Jimmy Connors post and an old tennis trophy. Jonathan lies in bed, flipping channels on a small TV. Typical late night stuff: infommercials; CNN; a Brazilian soccer match; "Channel J" (public access) on which X-rated clips advertise phone se Jonathan lingers a moment on these explicit ads back to, the roaring soccer crowd. He closes his eyes and drifts off to the frenetic Portuguese of an unseen announ
TWO CORPORATE LAWYERS are talking shop while pouring coff
Excuse me. Fixing his coffee, Jonathan reaches past them. They barel give him a glance as they continue their conversation.
So, the Knicks win last night?
I'm pretty sure, yeah.
Actually, they lost by 4. Both pause, turn to Jonathan. Jonathan smiles awkwardly.
It was supposed to be a good game though.
Oh. (back to Lawyer 2) Hey, so. did you get a chance to look over that memo from Watkins?
Bustling - yet here too Jonathan is ignored as he carries coffee past ASSISTANTS and LAWYERS talking shop. He smile (CONTINUED)

politely at those he passes; few bother to smile in retur INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - MORNING . Again Jonathan works alone at one end of the long table, rapidly typing, eyes ping-ponging from files to laptop, beside him a meticulous arrangement of pastel-colored pos its on which are scribbled various calculations. He strik us as extremely good at his job, tackling the overwhelmin array of numbers and data with methodical assurance. Taking a break, he pauses to peer out the glass wall befo him. Behind the glass, employees pass like fish in a tank

In a stall, Jonathan is staring sleepily at patterns in t stall's marble door -- when a sudden KNOCK-KNOCK on the divider to his right startles him. He peers down and over expensive black wingtip shoes, a Wall St. Journal spread the floor. Another KNOCK-KNOCK. Confused, Jonathan turns address the divider:
Yes?
Take a look at this. The voice sounds youthful, energetic. Its owner slides hi Journal along the floor halfway between the marble divisi
The Japanese are developing a toilet that can analyze your urine for glucose levels, kidney disease, even cancer. They're referring to it as the "super bowl."
That certainly is
Of course if you've ever been to Japan, you know they're nuts about their toilets. I'm talking web sites, symposiums... Jonathan chuckles.
You think I'm kidding. They have bowls over there that cost more than a piano. What I want to know is how you're supposed to retrieve this analysis - you know, from your super bowl. (CONTINUED)
Maybe they're developing a fly with a nursing degree. A superfly.
(LAUGHS)
Who's in there anyway?
Uh, Jonathan Messer.
Messer... What department?
None. I'm from Worth and Berman. I've been over here a few wee-- A FLUSH from the next stall cuts him off. The sound of zipping up, of a belt buckled, then of a stall door openi
So you're an accountant? Jonathan follows the FOOTSTEPS, now addresses his stall d
Audit manager, yeah.
So how's it work, Rutherford Stern hires Worth and Berman to give their blessing to our books, and they send you?
Have laptop, will travel. What about you?
What about me?
Well, I didn't get your name for one.th-- The SOUND OF A FAUCET RUNNING drowns him out.
.ose.
Sorry - I didn't catch that? (gets no response) Hello...? (CONTINUED)
I said it's Wyatt. Wyatt Bose. Jonathan FLUSHES, buckles his belt, opens his stall door - only the men's room is now empty.
Message-four. Three-oh-eight-pee-em.
Alone again, Jonathan listens to voice-mail on his cell phone. We..find two more batteries sitting ready in a cha

Jonathan? Chet Peterson. Just wanted to- confirm you're wrapping up over there at Rutherford Stern because the controller at Clancey has been on me to get someone in there by Thursday. I told him how brilliant you are, said you're the best auditor we've got. Anyway, I forwarded you some documentation... Jonathan clicks his mouse - to find 27 worth&berman.com. He reaches for his palm pilot, clicks o day planner, stylus writes "Clancey" into next week. Othe than places he'll be working, days-are-all entirely blank
Jonathan still working. Only a few of the post-its now re on the tabletop. Yawning, he glances at his watch -
12:53 Startled, Jonathan turns to a well-dressed young man in t doorway - penetrating eyes, playful smile, familiar voice
Sorry if I scared you. I was heading home and saw the lights. We met before, in the can...
Sure. It's Wyatt, right? WYATT BOSE nods as he steps into the room. There's someth very likeably "on" about him. (CONTINUED)
So do you normally work this late?
Pretty much. I'm supposed to be out of here by tomorrow so I'm just trying to finish up. What about you?

You kidding? This is an early night. Hard to believe that once upona time a man's success was measured by how little he had to work. You know in Sweden the average worker gets 7 weeks a year vacation? (regards his stacked files) Do-you like accounting?
It's all right, if you enjoy working with numbers. Do you like being a lawyer?
It's all right. If you enjoy working with assholes. Jonathan laughs, glances at his monitor screen.
Well, I'm probably disturbing you -
No - it's okay. Really.
So Worth and Berman, huh? Don't you have to like be in Mensa to work there? Jonathan smiles, shrugs modestly.
Been with them long?
Since my senior year of college. They subsidized my graduate degree.
Really. So you were poor? Jonathan is given pause by the bluntness of the question. (CONTINUED)
Well - I guess you could say that. I was raised by a single mother, and she died when I was nineteen, so... yeah. It wasn't so bad though. I'm sure a lot of people have had it worse.
Not around here. Practically every suit I know is Harvard by way of Andover.
Are you?
Me? Hell no... I'm Princeton. By way of Exeter. Jonathan laughs. Wyatt smiles, takes a few idle paces.
So. Jonathan. (GRINS)
What do you say to a break?

CLOSE ON A SCREENSAVER OF SWIMMING FISH. Tilt up from Jonathan's laptop screen to Wyatt and Jonathan, sitting o top of the expensive conference-table, passinga joint, staring out at the rain hammering the far windows.
(STONED)

.It's just sometimes I feel so - I don't know - removed. I mean, I work for one of the biggest accounting firms in the world, and.there's not so much as a desk there to prove it? They've decided all we need are cell phones and laptops. Messages are voice-mailed, documents e-mailed, salary's deposited online. Chet Peterson, my senior manager? I swear he wouldn't recognize me if I was sitting in his chair. Jonathan pauses, takes another drag, train of thought dri
I don't know... I used to have friends. But it's like I've spent so much time trying to prove myself, working these hours you look up and realize you've lost (CONTINUED)

everyone. Just - fell out of touch. With everyone... And I try to meet people at work. I do. But it's always the same. To the accounting staff I'm a pain because for two weeks they have to hold their breath and hope I don't pick up on any of their screw ups. And to everyone else, I'm just a temporary fixture, so why bother? The truth is, this is the first meaningful conversation I've had in I don't know how long. It's like if I disappeared tomorrow, I'm not .sure anyone other than Solange would even notice - she's my neighbor. I live on what must be the only block in Brooklyn that still isn't hip. (EXHALES)
I guess I just never counted-on the isolation. It's like sometimes I look through that glass, and I see life literally passing me by. Jonathan stares out the glass wall in stoned silence.
Jonathan?
Yeah?

just talked for Wyatt looks at Jonathan -- and cracks up. Jonathan hesita then he too starts to laugh so now they can't stop, their laughter filling the expansive room -- until it's drowned the SOUND ADVANCE OF POURING RAIN...

Jonathan hurries in the cold. rain for the Times Square subway. He's just about to descend - when across he spots a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN in a camel hair coat, clutching a slim briefcase, waiting to cross the street. Jonathan gazes at her, almost gasping. She's surrounded b pedestrians with umbrellas., she's the only one without o and she's DRENCHED. But she seems content to entertain herself drawing a pattern in the drops collecting on the umbrella in front of her. Jonathan watches, intrigued - and then the rumble of the subway below reminds him he'd better move. 10.

Jonathan stands in a long line to buy a Metrocard, his glasses steamed up. He takes them off to wipe the lenses. JONATHAN'S POV: the entire station is a blur, all unfocus muted colors, no object discernible from another - - until his glasses return his POV to immediate focus, an sees the same Young Woman in'the camel.hair coat, a pair dollar bills in her hand, entering the station. Jonathan can't help but stare again. Despite her business attire, there's an almost childlike lightness. to her ste Jonathan notices her slim briefcase. Beneath her hand, he make out the first letter of a monogram: "S." She checks out the long line for Metrocards, considers waiting, then decides life's too short. She continues pas headed for the turnstiles. Jonathan continues to observe as she raises her briefcase then proceeds to wriggle her slender frame through the na gap in the turnstile. A PANHANDLER on the other side watches her with amusement Glancing up, she catches his eye, and blushes a mischievo smile. Once she's through, she drops her money into his collection - and slips out of view. ANGLE ON JONATHAN, still stuck on line, staring at the sp she vacated.

Jonathan arrives as an N train pulls away, the platform n practically. empty. Weary and still a bit stoned, Jonathan peers sleepily int the dark expanse of tunnel, yawns - And then he sees "S" is waiting on the same platform. Ten yards away. He gazes at her. She's unwrapping some GUM. H watches as she puts a piece in her mouth. The sound of an ARRIVING N TRAIN. "S" heads for it, Jonat follows... The train halts. The door before him is the last of its c the door before her the first of the next. The doors open. (CONTINUED)
II S a II (turns to Jonathan) Excuse me, is this the train for canal Street? It takes Jonathan a second just to find his voice. She's more arresting up close.

Uh,.either one is R both stop there so, you know, either way, I mean, this is the right train. Yes. SOS Of Thanks. "S" enters her car. Jonathan wavers, wants to follow into car but doesn't have the nerve. He enters a different car
Jonathan's slumped against a window, annoyed. at himself not getting in her car. He can see 'S'. She sits in the other car chewing her gum studies her, he's absolutely knocked out by her.

Next stop Canal Street. Canal is next. He sees "S" rising to join the small crowd gathering by a door. Jonathan stands up - his last chance. Determined, he brac himself and rises, grasping his briefcase. The screeching of brakes as the train grinds into "CANAL

A sudden JOLT of the braking train.causes Jonathan to stu slightly and his briefcase BANGS against a seat and SNAPS OPEN - contents tumbling out. His cell phone hits the flo Jonathan quickly bends for his phone - when the train lur to a halt, nearly knocking him over, and sliding his cell phone a few feet along the grimy floor. O.S. we hear the hiss of the doors opening as Jonathan gr for his phone a second before it's stepped on. He hurried stuffs it in his pocket, shoves his files and papers and paraphernalia back into his briefcase and rises to his fe - to find the doors closing, and "S" gone. (CONTINUED)

Devastated, he hurries to a window, searching the platfor the train begins to depart... He can just glimpse the bac her camel hair coat as his car is sucked back into a tunn He stands helpless, just shuts his eyes and lowers his he

Jonathan is pouring coffee when he brightens on hearing W enter, talking animatedly with Lawyers telling his joke, Wyatt doesn't seem to notice Jonathan. Only when the lawyers burst out laughing does Wyatt glanc up. His eyes meet Jonathan's. Jonathan smiles in greeting but Wyatt just nods coolly, returns to his fellow lawyers Jonathan's smile falters. He exits wordlessly.
Jonathan hands over files and CD-Roms to a less than soci ASSISTANT CONTROLLER.
I guess that's it. then. Nice meeting you.
Uh huh. Jonathan turns to go, takes two paces - then turns back.
Listen - could you point me toward Wyatt Bose's office? The Assistant Controller looks up in mild annoyance.
Wyatt Bose. He's an attorney here. She sighs, put upon, then slides out a desk drawer in whi laminated page of names and extensions is taped. Jonathan eyes follow her lazy finger down the list --
Hey, quit looking down her shirt! Jonathan instinctively leaps back from her desk, turns to find Wyatt grinning at him from down the corridor.
Leaving, huh? So where to next? (CONTINUED)
Clancey Funds on Thursday. Clute Nichols after that. Wyatt's about to reply - when ANOTHER LAWYER passes him i the hall. Wyatt taps the lawyer's shoulder.
Hey, wait up a sec. (smiles back) Well, good meeting you, Jonathan. ,Wyatt turns and starts to walk off with the other lawyer Jonathan bends for his briefcase -
Wait, so you have off tomorrow? Jonathan looks up to Wyatt smiling at him from down the h
You don't happen to have .a. decent backhand, do you?

Beneath an enormous bubble dome, Jonathan and Wyatt play mixed doubles with two attractive YOUNG WOMEN (early 20's Between points, we observe from Jonathan's side of the ne Wyatt chatting up his partner. The rapport between Jonath and his partner is markedly less comfortable; he wipes hi brow, smiles at her, she forces a polite smile in return.

A good rally underway. Jonathan fires a backhand. Wyatt returns it with an audible grunt. Jonathan snaps the ball back to Wyatt's partner - only Wyatt intercepts, nailing back. Jonathan returns it with equal force. A grin on Wyatt's face as he savors the battle, blasting each ball. The women step aside. Jonathan lunges, barely managing to lob a return. Sensing victory, Wyatt raises h racket and with a guttural bark mercilessly smashes the b Jonathan dives, racket over-extended - and returns a near perfect shot just over Wyatt's head... but it lands inches outside the opposite baseline.
Out! (CONTINUED)
Jonathan curls forward, gasping for air. Silence - then Wyatt's SOLITARY APPLAUSE echoes in the humid space.
Commiserations, Messer. Good game. They shake hands at the net. Jonathan is exhausted.
(WARMLY)

Develop akiller instinct and you'll beat the crap out of me. Jonathan turns to commiserate with his partner - but she' already gone to join her friend. Jonathan crashes out on court. From his low angle he watches as Wyatt goes over t the girls and says something that causes a burst of laugh The girls finally wave goodbye. Wyatt hops over the net.
They asked if we'd fancy a post-game cocktail. Don't worry, I got us out of it. Jonathan is barely able to speak.
Oh? I would've been happy to.
Are you kidding? They're a couple of first years at Merrill. Screw that, we can do better. Hey, you OK? Jonathan nods as an amused Wyatt helps him to his feet.
Soft jazz plays as Wyatt leads Jonathan past the bar area Wyatt is admiring Jonathan's weathered tennis racket.
Man, I remember when these first came out. I think I was a frosh at boarding school. (chuckles; fingers a string) Jeez, are these strings natural gut?
Actually, it's a hybrid weave: natural gut and Kevlar. They're pretty obscure now. I should replace them, they're all frayed... (CONTINUED)

Looking up, Jonathan abruptly slows his pace, his eyes suddenly fixed on a woman sitting at the far end of the b From behind, it looks remarkably like "S"... Only, as she turns, her profile proves otherwise.
Wyatt and Jonathan in towels, heading for the showers. Jonathan still deep in the 'S' moment -
Have you ever considered contacts? Jonathan halts, confused to find Wyatt studying his face his eyeglasses in particular.
Huh? Oh - yeah, I tried once, but I was allergic to something in the solution.
Too bad. You have an attractive face. Your eyes especially. Jonathan looks self-conscious in his towel.
It's not a come on, just an observation. (considers him a beat) You don't get much, do you.
What - you mean sex?
No, flood insurance. How many women have you slept with?
Oh, I don't know, not a whole-
Of course you know. Everyone knows.
Maybe - four.
Maybe four? (CONTINUED)
Okay fine, just four. What about you?
Me? I have no idea.
What? You just said everyone -
I meant everyone like you. Confused, Jonathan looks up -- as Wyatt disappears into a shower stall.
Jonathan emerges freshly showered, a towel around his wai as he walks toward the rows of lockers.
Tonight?... Fine. I'm on the list? Jonathan finds Wyatt half-dressed, seated on a bench by a locker and talking on his cell phone.
There better be. Wyatt hangs up, looks up to find Jonathan staring, puzzle
Something wrong? Jonathan reaches into his locker for his hanging jacket, pulls out his own cell phone. It's identical to Wyatt's.
We have the same phone.
Oh - and you thought I was using yours? I can afford my own phone calls, you know.
No, I wasn't
I'm pulling your dick, Jonathan. (grins, slams his locker) Actually, I was just firming up some plans for tonight. Are you free? (CONTINUED)
(SURPRISED)
Me? Sure, I guess
You're not. What do you say, are you in?
I guess I could go home and change.
To Brooklyn? Forget it, you can borrow something of mine.
A three-story brownstone in an expensive West Village neighborhood. As Wyatt leads Jonathan to the staircase, t pass a papery-faced GENTLEMAN
t (glances back) This way, Jonathan.

Urban chic to a serious degree. Big terrace, funky furnit framed snapshots of Wyatt with similarly hip and attracti young friends - and great art, including an entrancing im of a burning candle just slightly out of focus.

Like it? It's a Gerhard Richter. Kleiner downstairs is a hot shot art dealer - he hooked me up with the gallery in Munich. Wyatt disappears into the next room. Alone, Jonathan wand pauses by the framed snapshots. The young people in them like Wyatt -- beautiful, strong, wealthy. Jonathan pauses one photo in which Wyatt looks a bit younger, his hair bleached blonde and loosely spiked.
Talk about a bad look. Startled, Jonathan quickly turns to find Wyatt standing r behind him,. a slick, expensive SUIT draped over his arm. (CONTINUED)
Here, try this one. (off Jonathan's hesitation) What?
Nothing, I just hope I can pull it off.
You hope you can pull it off. You know who you remind me of? James Getz.
Who?

A guy I roomed with freshman year at Princeton.. Real smart                                 - you loosened him up. Only from day one, he just didn't fit in. For starters, he was dirt poor. But it wasn't that. See, there was always this boundary - this wall - between Getz and everyone else. You could argue we laid the foundation, but he built it. Built it by believing the lie.
What lie?

That he was any different. The clothes, the money, the wry anecdotes - it's all one big masquerade. Anyone can get in, you've just got to wear a costume. But Getz never got that. He assumed he could never scale the wall, when the truth is he was the only one guarding it. It never occurred to him his anonymity could be an asset. No one gets over like the guy who's just a face, an impression. We are - all of us                                                  -
So what happened to him?
Who, James Getz? Oh - he killed himself.
(hesitates a beat) You're pulling my dick, aren't you. Wyatt turns to him with a grave look... then smirks. (CONTINUED)
With both hands. Jonathan can't help but laugh as Wyatt hands him the suit
He struts up to us, thumbs in his suspenders:
And now, straight from the Cafe Germaine, the Velvet Rope is proud to introduce you to the lovely Miss Lu Lu Lamour!

An ultra-elite "new burlesque" nightclub in Manhattan, Parisian decor. Strictly UPSCALE PATRONS, male and female sip from crystal barware, while on stage a BETTY PAGE TYP performs an elegantly choreographed strip tease. Wyatt and Jonathan sit at a small table; each table is fi with. an old-fashioned black rotary telephone, as well as small monitor recessed into the tabletop on which old sta films play silently. All part of the wink-wink ambience.
It's a little self-conscious, but I thought you'd get a kick out of it. How's that suit working out?
Oh - great, actually.
Keep it then. I've got two just like it. Jonathan's about to protest, when a WAITRESS arrives.
Two Macallan 25 year. Enjoy, gentlemen.
Isn't this like fifty bucks a glass?
We'll try not to spill any. (regards the floor show) So what's the wildest thing you've ever done? Sexually, I mean. (CONTINUED)
The wildest thing? Oh I don't know, I've never been too adventuresome.
All right, what's the lamest thing then?
The lamest... Wyatt's focused on him, amused, eager to hear it.

Actually, that was probably a few months ago. I was flipping through money magazine and saw this small ad in the back. It read something like "Are. you feeling all alone? Looking to meet women but have forgotten how?" And-there was this number.
And you called it? So what happened?
Nothing actually. The phone just kept ringing. And that's it. Wyatt stares at Jonathan a beat, then starts to crack up.
Lame enough for you?

You called a sex ad - from Money Magazine. That is beyond lame. Jonathan too starts laughing - when the phone at their ta lights'up. Wyatt looks to Jonathan, raises a brow - then picks up. He listens a moment, smiles, hands it to Jonath
.Hello? Wyatt taps his shoulder, directs his gaze to a SEXY BRUNE at a distant table, receiver to her ear, eyeing Jonathan.
.All right... Goodbye. Jonathan hangs up, turns to Wyatt.
She wants to dance. 21.

Jonathan is slow dancing with the sexy Brunette to an old Edith Piaf ballad. He looks over her shoulder to his tabl where Wyatt is sitting, talking on his cell phone. Glancing up, Wyatt's eyes meet Jonathan's; he flashes a p smile. Jonathan continues dancing, truly enjoying himself The Brunette leans in, whispers something in his ear...

head_text.subj: BACK TO WYATT AND JONATHAN'S TABLE

text: Wyatt clicks off his cell phone, looks up to find Jonatha returning alone, looking deflated.
She's a hooker. Wyatt shrugs, grinning.
Hold on - you knew? What - are all the women here prostitutes?

That depends on what you mean by that word. Stretch the definition and you could incorporate most of the men as well. (sips his drink) You know in Amsterdam prostitutes not only belong to a union, they have to pay taxes.
You seem to possess quite a store of international trivia.

Not really. I just get around... Jonathan, relax. It's not like she just shot your dog. I was only trying to help. Besides, what are you looking for - a relationship? As if you have time for one? This was your first day off in how long?
Three weeks.
Four for me. Face it, we've mortgaged our youth. Pimped out our twenties. But we still have needs. And there's nothing shameful about wanting them met. (CONTINUED)
So you sleep with hookers?
(LAUGHING)
Me? Never.
So how do you - meet your needs? Wyatt studies him a beat, another French love song drifti in the background as the Emcee introduces a new girl.
What if I told you... (breaks off, laughs) Christ, I sound like an infommercial.
What were you going to say?
Listen. You don't think that women have these same urges? Young women, just like ourselves, successful and working their asses off to stay that way? You better believe they do.
And?
And - well - let's just say, there's a way...a way it can be taken care of.
You make it sound like a mob hit. Wyatt smiles, and turns his attention back to the floor s
Wyatt and Jonathan are in the back seat. A quiet beat.
What you were talking about, before. Peoples' needs... Wyatt turns to Jonathan with a grin:
Some other time. (to Cabbie) (CONTINUED)
At the corner, please. The Rhiga Royal. (to Jonathan) Listen, I have to meet someone..
(SURPRISED)
Oh... okay. The cab pulls up before the RHIGA ROYAL HOTEL.
Hey. You had a good time tonight?
Yeah. Yeah I did. Thanks.
I'm glad. Listen, that thing with the hooker, I'm really sorry if I
Forget it. It was funny. Wyatt smiles warmly, pats Jonathan's shoulder.

I'll give you a call tomorrow. Wyatt Wyatt disappears into the golden glow of the lobby. LATER: Driving in the cab, Jonathan catches his reflectio the glass. He smiles, liking how he looks in Wyatt's suit Outside, rainy Manhattan passes by ina hypnotic blur.
(To driver) Hey. Could you let me out at the next corner over there, on 7th Avenue?

Jonathan stands in the exact spot where he first saw "S". He buys a New York Times and a hot-dog. Pedestrians and theatre crowds pass by as he remains root to the spot,.hoping he'll see that face in the crowd. After a while he shakes his head at the ridiculousness of and heads down into the-subway.
Clancey's stiff CONTROLLER Jonathan as he unloads files onto the huge conference tab (CONTINUED)
Beside him we see he's set up his laptop, phone charger, pencils and a fresh, unopened pack of pastel post-its.

Any problems, you'll want to see Julie Levinson, she's our assistant controller or if she's busy, Scott Werner, our senior accountant. If Werner's unavailable, we have two staff accountants said, I don't anticipate any problems. I mean we've never had any before, so...
Right.I just need the access codes for the accounts and sub-accounts? The Controller suddenly looks uneasy.
You've got account numbers, but no access codes. Without those I can't get the banks to authorize statement verification. (beat; smiles) Besides, how else can I steal the money?
What?
Nothing, I was just pulling your-- leg. I do need those codes though, when you get a chance.

Other than Jonathan's suit and tie, the reduced number of post-its and the lighter stack of files Jonathan is hunched over his laptop. Like Rutherford Ster conference room, this one too is designed with a glass wa Jonathan peers out at workers passing in utter indifferen to him. Slightly different tank, slightly different fish. CLOSE ON A BUSINESS CARD: a Rutherford Stern masthead, beneath it Wyatt's name and office number. Jonathan picks his cell phone and dials it. RING... RING -
Hey, Jonathan.
How'd you know it was- (CONTINUED)
You really ought to block your caller ID. So - same place as yesterday?
Along the entire square of ledge, throngs of SUITED BUSIN TYPES bundled in scarves eating street vendor fare. It's we find Wyatt and Jonathan, having a quick bite.

I wonder what the Founding Fathers would make of this scene. Wyatt regards face after face of young men and women wear expensive suits, wolfing down lunch so they can get back work - a good 2/3 of them talking on cell phones as they

I'm just glad to be outside. (awkwardly heartfelt) I've got to tell you, this has been great, meeting up for lunch. I used to just- A cell phone RINGS. They both instinctively reach in thei jackets, take out their identical phones. It's Wyatt's th ringing. Jonathan rests his down on the ledge.
Yes?... Shit. Okay, see if you can.gettme on the 6:15 Wyatt rests his phone on the ledge next to Jonathan's.
Rutherford needs me to join him asap in London to paper some financing with Lloyds. I tell you about this?
No - no you didn't.
Yeah, I should be gone a few weeks. Jonathan tries to mask the wave of loneliness setting in.
Sounds exciting.
Nah, it'll be boring as sin. (CONTINUED)
Wyatt studies him a moment, grabs his cell phone and rise from the ledge.
Shit, I'd better get back. You ready?
Sitting before his laptop, Jonathan takes out his cell ph and punches in some numbers.
He enters the numbers again, receives the same prerecorde message. He hangs up -- when it abruptly RINGS, surprisin him. He stares at the phone a curious beat, then answers
Jonathan Mess- CLICK. Dead air. More puzzled, Jonathan frowns a beat replaces the battery with one fresh off the charger.
As ignored as ever, Jonathan is squeezed among EMPLOYEES their way home. TWO SECRETARIES speak in hushed tones:
.That's just it. You caught him in a lie, so now everything he says you have to- RING of a cell phone. RING... RING... It's Jonathan's. Surprised, he takes out the phone, presses talk.
Hello? A soft, electronic rustle from the other end... then:
Are you free tonight?
Excuse me?
I asked if you're free tonight.
I'm sorry, I think you have the wrong-- (CONTINUED)

Because I needed to see you again. I needed to be sure you were all right. Despite his conflicting emotions, Jonathan is moved S,f I didn't know how to find you - you were just a number in a cell phone, and (CONTINUED)
'is" Jonathan had taken that. I remembered you took this train -
Wait, Jonathan? I'm Jonathan. Jonathan Messer. You're O.S. we hear the approaching roar of an INCOMING TRAIN... ii S Did you go to the police?
I can't. He's framing me for murder. What?

He killed a woman from the club, someone I'd been with. "S" is shocked., instantly terrified. Clearly she had no I/ S$f Jonathan, you have to leave! Do you understand? You need to get the hell out of here, he's going to kill you! The roar of the incoming train is growing LOUDER... Don't you understand? He's going to kill - - when the INCOMING TRAIN completely drowns him out... an swipes "S" out of Jonathan's view. Jonathan struggles to peer through the train windows but passengers prevent him from getting a look at her. Just t the TRAIN DOORS OPEN WITH THE NOISE of passengers getting and off. Panicked, Jonathan cranes his neck, trying to se her through the windows.
He boards the train; using it as a bridge, he pushes thro passengers, desperate for an open door to the other side. (CONTINUED)

Shuttle to New York's Grand Central Station. Grand Central is next. He jumps off the train, in the direction she'd been walki -- only she's nowhere in sight. Jonathan spins franticall the doors close and he hears the TRAIN START TO PULL AWAY He runs alongside the train - desperately searching for a glimpse of her .until the last car passes the rear observation window, her hand pressed to the pane her tearful expression bidding him a heartbreaking goodby He stumbles to a devastated halt, eyes pleading vainly as watches her recede, framed by the rectangle of window, directly beneath it the train's steel. exterior labelled shuttle line's circled black and white S.
TILT DOWN FROM THE CONSTELLATIONS of the vaulted ceiling the tiny figure of "S," standing at the ticket counter, staring uneasily through bars at a TICKET AGENT.
Let's see - there's one to New Haven, leaving in... six minutes. If you need to go farther, you can transfer from there. "S" peers anxiously around her, like someone hunted.
And that's the very next train leaving?

Only a few scattered travellers this late. "S" slumps int seat, takes a breath - and starts to quietly break down. shuts her eyes, tries to stifle her sobbing. A man's hand extends a handkerchief from the seat behind azSaz No thank you. RACK FOCUS on the man withdrawing his handkerchief behind her, grinning coolly to himself: it's-Wyatt.
Suit yourself. (CONTINUED)
RACK BACK TO "S" as her eyes blink open in terror --
Jonathan yanks open his mailbox. Empty. As he heads upsta there's a change in his face: a newly forged determinatio He takes out his cell phone, dials. The other end immedia picks up:
Jonathan Messera Jonathan hangs up. Takes an angry breath. Presses redial.
He hangs up again. But his face bears a blank, eerily dri expression. He hits redial again as he opens the door to
Jonathan enters, phone still to his ear.

Jonathan hangs up and just stares at the phone in his han on the verge of something like a scream. He takes a breat Presses redial once more. Only now it RINGS. Jonathan freezes. RING... RING... RING... RING... RING -- a CLICK someone picking up, then SILENCE and faint wisps of stati
Hello...? Not a word from the other end. We barely make out BREATHI
Wyatt? Is that you? Jonathan takes a tentative step forward, as if fearful th the least movement will cost him this connection.
Say something damn it! From the receiver we hear a well-exhaled breath. And then (CONTINUED)
(sung in a low whisper) Yesterday... Reeling, Jonathan grips the phone tighter to his ear.
All my troubles seemed so far away...
What do you want from me?
Now it seems as though -
Answer me!
- they're here to stay, Oh I believe
Why are you doing this to me?!
- in yester--
I'm going to find you, you hear me? I'm- CLICK. Dead air.
Hello?... Hello?! Jonathan SLAMS the phone down, tension in his face joined a new emotion, something closer to. fury.
I'm going to find you.
Jonathan is heading for the Clute Nichols building, that focused tension on his face -
Mr. Messer? Jonathan is too lost in thought to hear it.
Jonathan. (CONTINUED)
He glances up... to find Russo standing near the entryway what's she doing here? He has no choice but to meet her.
I was gonna call, but I was in the area. Just doing some follow-up. Jonathan tries to mask his uneasiness.
Follow-up?
On that missing girl of yours. The.one whose name began with. an "S." Have any luck finding her? Jonathan absently tightens his grasp on his briefcase.
No. No luck.
I see. That's too bad. she studies him a cryptic beat, then smiles flatly.
Well, who knows, maybe she'll turn up yet. You have a good day, Mr. Messer. Jonathan nods tensely, then walks off, feeling her watchi him from the curb as he goes.

Employees pass by the glass behind which we see Jonathan lone figure at his laptop, surrounded by files and post-i Close on Jonathan as he scribbles on a post-it: "Yesterda Beatles?" Widen to find the post-its organized with his u fastidiousness "Wyatt Bose = William Bansky" and other random scribbling He's trying to apply his mathematical mind to his crisis, hoping to conjure some kind of pattern or logic to it all Reverse angle through the glass: to anyone passing, he lo like your typical overly meticulous, isolated auditor. Closer on Jonathan as he clutches the table, looks second away from utterly losing it -- when something suddenly oc to him. He whips around, gaze fixing on (CONTINUED)
His cell phone. He grabs it. Presses a key repeatedly - scanning ear, listens for the other end; then:
Are you free tonight?
Jonathan waits anxiously by a Botero sculpture of a rotun dog. A young woman in a BLUE PASHMINA approaches.
Blue Pashmina enters first, Jonathan follows her into an empty elevator. The doors close.
Do you know Wyatt Bose?
(immediately guarded) Excuse me?
What about William Bansky? Does that name-- She darts.for the "Door Open" button, but he blocks her p
I swear to God I'll scream.
Please, I'm not trying to scare you, I just very important that I find him. she tries to push past him, again Jonathan blocks her.

He does this too - or he did. someone had to give him the numbers. Someone let him in. If I can-'find who it was that knew him, they might know where he's she suddenly kicks him in the shin with a spiked heel. Jonathan grasps his leg - she presses the button and is o the opening doors before he's even looked up. SOUND ADVANCE: TENSE CLACKING of computer keys... 88.
CLOSE ON JONATHAN alone at the end of the conference tabl eyes scanning files absently, fingers typing on auto-pilo His gaze holds a new determination, as the CLACKING OF KE

Jonathan anxiously escorts ANOTHER YOUNG WOMAN past the q Moroccan motif. Asking her something, he takes out a fold paper from his pocket, shows it to her: it's the photocop Bansky's license with the image of Wyatt's face. She quic shakes her head, her eyes searching for the exit.

Jonathan trails a TALL WOMAN as she bee-lines for the exi He grabs her arm, thrusts the photocopy into her hands. S halts, looks up at him... and tears it in two before hand it back and hurrying off, her glare full of paranoia.

Jonathan rises from a couch to greet YET ANOTHER YOUNG WO He gets no more than a few seconds into his question when about-faces without a word. Jonathan has a relentless loo his eye. Takes out his cell, calls another number...

Rapid jump cuts of A DOZEN DIFFERENT WOMEN'S FACES, all indicating twenty different kinds of "no"; with each cut women occupy the exact same position in frame, only their faces and the hotel backgrounds behind them change.
Room key in hand, Jonathan rides up with a woman in a BLA BUSINESS SUIT - a tall, attractive business-type. Jonatha stares at his shoes, trying to mask his. utter exhaustion
Jonathan and Black Business Suit come in. She starts to
I need to ask you something, it's incredibly important... (CONTINUED)

He pauses to unfold his now scotch-taped photocopy, shows to her. She freezes, eyes fixed on the license photo. Jonathan braces himself for her departure back up at him in scared but clear recognition.
Seated on the edge of the made bed, Black Business Suit shifts uncomfortably as she lights a cigarette.
I was in Chicago on business, a little over a year ago. I was out.to dinner with one of our Chicago partners,.a man named Holloway. That's how I met him. TIGHT ON JONATHAN as we SMASH TO:
A slightly older man Across from him sits Black Business Suit. A YOUNGER MAN s into frame, rests his hand on Holloway's shoulder.
At first I assumed he was a junior executive at their firm. But he wasn't. That's not to say he didn't work for Holloway, but clearly in a more intimate capacity...
Black Business Suit takes a cool drag on her cigarette.
I wasn't shocked. Besides, obviously I'm no prude. Even back then, I'd been doing - you know, this thing -- for a while.
Wyatt is talking, entertaining his two companions - but clearly more focused on Black Business Suit, flirting it

I was simply curious. More so when he apologized, explaining that he'd forgotten about another engagement. Wyatt's knuckles just barely stroke Black Business Suit's thigh as he rises to leave. They exchange a knowing glanc (CONTINUED)

I was intrigued. He was intelligent, informed about everything from law to art to politics. I'd never met anyone so in command of his own charm. He said that he'd come from nothing, that everything he learned, he learned from his tricks. He claimed that Holloway was even grooming him for a position at his company. She lights another cigarette with her old one.
In a way, I felt for him. But I also admired him. It sounds silly,. but he had a way of making me feel - close to him, you know? This clearly hits home with Jonathan. He barely nods.
So I found myself telling him things.. Personal things. And, next thing I knew -
You told him. About this. A beat, and she nods, crushing out her other cigarette.
He seemed fascinated by it. Wanted to know all the details. (EXHALES)
I suppose I'd had too much to drink. And I was distracted... I was thinking about what a great lay he was going to be.

Wyatt and Black Business Suit go at it with animal aggression. She's on all fours, arching lustily, pleasure nearly unbearable, eyes clenched shut as she climaxes. Exhausted, her body goes limp. TILT UP to his face: an eerily blank, driven stare, devoi real pleasure. She struggles, tries to protest - when his hands grip her shoulder blades, thrusting harder, violent pinning her down, her sudden fear stifled by the mattress
CLOSE ON Black Business Suit staring off, chilled by memo (CONTINUED)

Only afterwards I discovered two of my credit cards were missing. As was my cell phone. Of course I couldn't say anything to Holloway. And Jamie must have known I'd never report it to the police. (BEAT)
So I just put the incident out of my mind. I all but forgot about it, until one night, maybe two months ago -
Black Business Suit is crossing the lobby for a portrait Hearst and A SUITED MAN lingering beneath it... when the looks up. It's Wyatt.
I almost didn't recognize him. But when I did, I suddenly felt very, very scared. She freezes -- obscured by one of the trees as Wyatt chec his watch, scans-the lobby with a cool, piercing look.

head_text.subj: BACK TO BLACK BUSINESS SUIT AND JONATHAN IN THE MICHELANG

text: I left before he saw me. She drags on her cigarette, looks off into space.
He must have used my cell phone to get into the group. (crushes out her cigarette) Anyway, that's it. That's all I know. She looks around. At the room, the bed. She shudders, ris
Wait - thank you. (off her look) Have you ever run into him again?
Getz? No. And I don't ever want to.
Getz?
That was his name. Jamie Getz. 92.
Bundled in her ski jacket, Solange is closing up her shop the night, stacks of flowers in her arms, when she notice Jonathan coming down the front steps.
Jonathan, you're home early - Only when he looks up, she finds the young man in the overcoat isn't Jonathan. It's Wyatt.
Oh - je suis desole. My mistake. Wyatt flashes her an icy smile, continues down the steps. Solange watches him walk away, a puzzled look on her face
Huddled over a computer, Jonathan typing, eyes red from exhaustion and stress as we hear his recall:
who's James Getz?

A guy I roomed with freshman year at Princeton. on Jonathan's monitor we see he's on a web site for Princ University alumni. He types in: Getz, James. A beat - then: "No match." A long list of G names follows Jonathan scrolls down the list, but there's no Getz.

Shit. Jonathan exhales, about to log off - when a name among th H's jumps out at him: Holloway. Reed. Jonathan stares at it tensely - then clicks on the name. "Sort no contact information available." Jonathan thinks a moment - then tries a search engine, ty "Holloway Reed" then decides to add the word "missing." An article appears. From the Chicago Tribune: "BODY OF MISSING BUSINESSMAN FINALLY DISCOVERED." A head-shot styl photograph shows a man in his early 40s whom we recognize from Black Business Suit's story. Beneath his photo, his name: "Reed Holloway." (CONTINUED)
Jonathan glances up at the Hotel employee manning the des
Can I print this out?
Porn shops and prostitutes, the streets pulsing with a sinister energy. Jonathan is pacing toward the subway, reading over the printed article.

Jonathan descends the steps to his presently deserted neighborhood. O.S. the departure of the subway train is joined by the distant.wail of SIRENS. Jonathan continues down the block, then pauses. He wrinkl his nose, smelling something. He looks up: two blocks awa thick plume of smoke is billowing up into the sky --

Jonathan bolts around the corner to find an ambulance and fire engine curbside -- a fire raging in the lower story his building! Running toward the blaze, he speeds past a BLACK BMW park across the street, engine running. It suddenly shifts int gear and peels out in a fast turn. Jonathan spins about it troubling him - but the BMW is already gone. He continues racing toward his building... The neon "FLEURS DE SOLANGE" sign crackles and sparks in flame. Through blown out windows, piles of burning flower emit what must be an awful stench. Two EMS WORKERS are loading a gurney on which Solange lay burned and half-aware, but alive, when Jonathan rushes ov She manages to open her eyes, her voice barely audible:
Jonathan... He squeezes her hand as she's lifted into the ambulance.
(to EMS worker) Is she going to be okay?
Yeah, she'll make it. (CONTINUED)
The ambulance doors SLAM shut. A hand grabs Jonathan's ar He spins
I live here.

Thick smoke clouds the stairs and corridor. Suit jacket o his head, Jonathan is hurriedly escorted by the Fire Work His own door has already been kicked open, splintered at hinges. The place looks like it's been turned upside down furniture soaking wet, charred areas on walls.
Lucky we were able to contain it somewhat. Better get your valuables together.
still in shock, he tosses random clothes in a gym bag - " on Bike" too.
(calls out) How did it start?
We're not sure. Maybe a bad fuse.
Jonathan opens his medicine cabinet, takes out his small cannister, uncaps it to see how much money he has left. N very much. He stuffs the cannister into his pants pocket.

Jonathan opens his old gunmetal-gray filing cabinet, then pops open his briefcase, trying to decide what to take. He finds a file marked "Bank Statements," pulls it, about toss it in his briefcase - when he stops, something about contents --- CLOSE ON THE FILE. Stuffed with paper. But not bank statements... Copies and copies of photographs of Jonatha with Simone Forester. Some we've seen, some new. Jonathan hunts through more files, his breathless nausea telling us the contents of each and every file have been swapped out with photos. (CONTINUED)

He opens another at random - and freezes: it's a photo of Jonathan and "S" walking in Chinatown. He scans through others, shots of them in the restaurant, entering the Hot Lotus... TIGHT ON JONATHAN, terrified by the horrific implication
Mr. Messer? Jonathan gasps as he looks up to find the Fire Worker in doorway. He quickly shuts the file.
Just
A paranoid-looking Jonathan returns with a briefcase stuf near to bursting. The tired Fire Worker looks up impatien
That everything? Jonathan regards his minimal possessions, realizes how li evidence there is of a life. A wrenching sense of isolati
I guess it is.
You got someone you can stay with?
The sort of decrepit no-tell motel frequented by hookers junkies. Jonathan clutches his briefcase as he stares thr steel mesh at. the NIGHT CLERK.
It's fifty for the night. Jonathan fishes out his film cannister, and parts with wh he discovers are his last three
Even more depressing than the lobby: bars on the windows, stains on the thin walls through which the faint sounds o paid sex bleed in. Somewhere a bottle smashes. (CONTINUED)

Unable to sleep, Jonathan has emptied his briefcase conte onto the bed. He stares at one of Wyatt's photos of him a "S." She's smiling up at him. EXTREME CLOSE ON THE IMAGE OF HER FACE. The smile, frozen time, at once haunting and heartbreaking. He gently sets the photo down beside the Chicago Tribune article he'd printed on the unsolved murder of Reed Hollo ("BODY OF MISSING BUSINESSMAN FINALLY DISCOVERED"). His e drift to the article, and something suddenly occurs to hi FLASH ON: THE PHOTOGRAPH IN "WYATT'S.BROWNSTONE" of Wyatt with bleached hair styled in a loose spike -- IN THE ARTICLE'S PHOTO, Holloway sports an almost identic look.-His eyes move to the date of the article: "May 17."
Jonathan on the phone, a business card in hand.
Boston Police, how can I direct your call? Jonathan reads off the card Detective Russo had given him
number 274655. Jonathan sits in suspense, awaiting a response. Finally -
Well?
You've got a case, a missing person named William Bansky. I'm wondering if you can tell me the date he was last seen?
Hold a sec. (PAUSE)
Bansky, William, last seen... May Jonathan's eyes return to the Holloway article MISSING BUSINESSMAN FINALLY DISCOVERED:), dated "May 17."
Anything else you- (CONTINUED)

That's it, thanks. Jonathan quickly hangs up, equally encouraged and chilled the connection he's made. TILT DOWN to a post-it, on which he's scribbled: "BOSE = BANSKY = HOLLOWAY." To this he adds: "= JAMES GETZ"
A line of customers stare mutely up at plasma tv screens above - except for Jonathan, unshaven, suit wrinkled, fac all anxious tension.
Jonathan slides his passport through the window's metal t to the TELLER Teller examines the passport, then slides it back.
M'kay, if you'll just swipe your ATM card. She gestures to a small punch pad to Jonathan's right.
Actually, my card was stolen.
Mmm'kay... do you see those two taupe colored telephones over there? Just pick up either one and you'll be connected with our automated system.

The thing is, I already used your automated system and...look, this passport's all I have left, it's the only thing proves who I am and now I'm down to like my last ten dollars here, so... Jonathan's cool is cracking. The Teller wrinkles her brow
Mm'kay, if you press "0" on either phone? A customer service representative will -
Give me a goddamn break. (CONTINUED)
Sir, there's no need for profanity.

(loses it) Oh no? In the last few days I've seen a woman I thought might be dead turn up alive and a woman I assumed was alive turn up dead, both at the hands of a guy about whom everything I know is apparently a lie. I've had my building set on fire, my neighbor nearly killed, and my apartment ransacked. So please forgive my language, but it's been one fuck of a week. The stunned Teller stares back at him slack-jawed.

Look, I know I'm just another face on this side of the glass, I get that. But I'm begging you, as one human being to another, please let me into your life just long enough to help me out here. Please. The Teller stares back at him a beat - and nods. She starts quickly typing into her monitor, finally looks
I'm showing that card as having been sent out four days ago. It definitely went out. We even heeded the change of address request.
Well, like I
Apparently you informed the bank of an address change? She swivels her monitor so he can see.
Mr. Jonathan Messer,

AS SEEN FROM THE CONVEX MIRROR OF AN ATM MACHINE: we watc from an ANONYMOUS POV Jonathan racing out of the bank. 99. EXT. INT. We recognize the DOORMAN in the midst of fielding a compl by an ELDERLY TENANT with a yappy dog. Jonathan hurries t the elevators, unnoticed. INT. Jonathan emerges from an elevator. The last door on the l Jonathan tries the doorknob. It's locked. Jonathan checks under the mat. Sure enough, there's a key.

Utterly bare. Empty walls, expensive views, polished wood floors. Jonathan takes a wary step inside, leaning to pee around the corners. He paces cautiously through the living room. The dining a The glistening chrome and granite kitchen.

A room as empty as the others - with the exception of a s pile of envelopes beneath a window in a far corner. Jonat slowly nears...to find it's a stack of mail. He picks up envelope -- O.S. the CREAK of a door hinge. Jonathan whips around -- no one behind him. He steps out the room to investigate. We remain alone in the empty room an excruciating beat... .until Jonathan finally steps back in, only slightly at ease. He returns to the stack of mail, picks up an envelo He reads: "Mr. Jonathan Messer 140 E. Eyes wide, he hurriedly flips through the rest of the mai all addressed to him at this address. Jonathan still staring at this mail in disbelief, when he finds at the bottom of the stack: another PHOTOGRAPH. It' "S" standing fearfully on the subwa latform across the track from Jonathan. And suddenly Jonathan is gripped wit fear, unaware of a blurred, nearing intruder...
Long time no see. (CONTINUED)
Jonathan spins round, Wyatt's standing there with a gun. pointing directly at Jonathan.
I have some instructions. Follow them and I might let her live.
Where is she?
This should've been simpler. I frame you, you panic...
Where is she?! A terrifying silence - Jonathan erupts:
Goddamn it tell me what you did to--

Press pause on the questions and listen. The brokerage firm you're auditing is Clute Nichols. As a standard part of that audit you're temporarily privy to all client accounts as well as access codes required for transactions. At tonight you're going to skim from those accounts a total of transfer that money to an account I've established overseas.
I can't
I know you don't. But I do. Your passport. (brandishes the gun) Now, please. Jonathan takes it out and tosses it to him. Wyatt catches And hands Jonathan an ENVELOPE.
It's all in there.
It won't work - they screen for stuff like this. It'll be discovered eventually. (CONTINUED)
I can live with eventually. I always have.
This account overseas                                   - isn't it? A moment of tense silence. Jonathan just stares back hard a quiet beat; then:
Why'd you pick me? Wyatt raises a brow, vaguely amused the question.

You answered the ad, Jonathan. (off Jonathan's confusion) "Feeling all alone out there? Have a great job, fine personality and good looks to match, but no time to.meet that special someone? Help is just a phone call away -"
The ad - in Money magazine...
(GRINS)
Told you to block that Caller ID. Of course I had to scope out a whole lot of losers before I hit the jackpot. After all, there only so many Jonathan Messers out there. (BEAT)
If you screw with me, well - you saw what I did to that Blonde? That's kindness compared to what I'll do to your little .girlfriend. You won't even recognize her when I'm through.
Why should I believe you? Everything you told me was lies.
Not lies, Jonathan. Foreplay. And now... now you're fucked. He grins his 'charming' grin and starts for the door. (CONTINUED)
Remember: be smart. I'll be watching you. And... feel free to take a shower, looks like you could do with one. The front door slams. Jonathan just stands there, staring shell-shocked at the envelope.

Jonathan comes out the building putting the envelope in h suit pocket. As he crosses the street a CAR HORN BLARES - WHIP AROUND find a car barrelling at us. Jonathan dives out of the wa instant before the car would have hit him. Face first in the gutter, scraped and gasping, Jonathan p up to see Wyatt's BLACK BMW speeding away.
A stiff guy in his late-30s is working in his office when ASSISTANT enters.
Mr. Peterson, one of the audit managers is here to see you. Jonathan Messer?
(PUZZLED)
Really? Well - okay, bring him back. We follow the assistant out the door, read the name stencilled on the glass "CHET PETERSON, SENIOR MANAGER."

Through a set of frosted glass doors we see Peterson's Assistant approach a RECEPTIONIST, who gestures across th lobby. The Assistant approaches the sofas, where Jonathan seated. She addresses him. He rises.
Chet Peterson looks up as his door is opened -
Jonathan, good to see you again! (CONTINUED)
- reverse angle to find a YOUNG MAN we've never seen befo
Actually, I was just looking for Fred Whipple's office?
(AWKWARDLY)
Next door down. The Young Man ducks out, and now Peterson sees his Assist approaching, Jonathan a few paces behind her, adjusting h glasses. Peterson reloads his greeting:
Jonathan, good to see you again!
Close on Chet Peterson, gravely peering across his desk.
Well, I have to say, your resignation comes as something of a surprise. Most of our auditors seem to like the freedom the position affords. (CONCERNED)
You'll stay on to finish up at Clute Nichols, of course? Track around Peterson to see Jonathan seated across from lifting his head to reply - and doing so revealing it's
Wyatt," wearing one of Jonathan's suits, hair colored and styled like Jonathan's, even sporting identical eyeglasse He offers an awkward half-smile, just as Jonathan would.
Absolutely.
So do you have any plans?
Yes. I'm going to travel. I want to see the world. Peterson nods benignly.

head_text.subj: A SERIES OF QUICK DISSOLVES/ STOP-MOTION PHOTOGRAPHY

text: Jonathan sitting in the conference room of Clute Nichols, lettered-boxed by the glass wall through which he watches employees pass in fewer and fewer numbers. Throughout thi Jonathan's blank stare of harrowed tension never changes.
Abeautiful shot of the cityscape - accompanied by the sou of fingers clacking on keys...

Jonathan seated at the far end of the empty table, typing his laptop. Beside him is the envelope Wyatt gave him, an its sheet of paper on which instructions are typed. Jonathan peers at the laptop clock. It reads His eyes travel in a tense triangle from instructions, to laptop screen, to glass wall - fingers typing all the whi He finally reaches a prompt: BIENVENUE. POUR ANGLAIS, CBO We glimpse a small. logo with a SWISS FLAG. Jonathan presses F2. Reads some more, types some more. Finally we read: ENTER SUB-ACCOUNT NUMBER. Jonathan enters more per Wyatt's typed instructions. Read
Jonathan copies the numbers in from the instructions. Wai

head_text.subj: ENTER SENDER'S 8 DIGIT ACCESS CODE. REQUIRED TO COMPLETE

text: His eyes travel to a page atop a Clute Nichols file. We c glimpse an 8 digit code circled in pencil. Jonathan stare the cursor.on the laptop screen, the icon blinking petulantly. He's about to type... And then he halts. His eyes drifting to HIS CELL PHONE, resting in its charger. TIGHTER ON JONATHAN. His eyes fixed on the cell phone, an idea forming in his mind -- RING!! of the cell phone suddenly jars us. RING... Jonath hesitates, then picks up.
What's taking you? (CONTINUED)
Jonathan says nothing. We can hear Wyatt getting tenser:
I said what's taking you?
I wondered if you were monitoring this.
Don't worry about what I'm doing. Just finish the transaction. Now.

Not until I see her. (off Wyatt's silence) The transfer's impossible without an access code. And there's no way I'm entering it until I'm sure that she's safe. So you tell me. How do we do that? Wyatt still remains unnervingly silent. We tighten on Jonathan, holding his breath, any plan he's concocting clearly hinging on this...
(low, frustrated) You have a wireless connection? Jonathan lets out a brief exhalation.

Jonathan snaps his laptop lid shut, packs it in his gym b in which we glimpse the photo he's kept with him of "S" smiling up at him. He then turns to his cell phone once more. He picks it up scrolls the menu, punches a number.
Hello?
(BEAT)
Are you free tonight? A sudden, jarring SOUND ADVANCE OF MUSIC as we

An elaborate and intensely packed WEDDING PARTY is being up here beneath the glow of heat lamps, the music and cro noise unspeakably loud. We travel through the din, past hundreds of well-heeled partiers, mainly young and wealth
The party noise is even slightly audible where we find Jonathan carrying his bag as he enters...
Jonathan surveys the busy lobby. GUESTS mulling. STAFF bustling. And, of course, the "ELOISE" PORTRAIT.

May I ask you a personal question? Jonathan spins around, stares frostily into Wyatt's magne smile. With Wyatt's new look, they could be brothers. Except Wyatt looks clean and crisp, Jonathan dishevelled tense. Wyatt eyes the bag in Jonathan's hand.
Where is she?
In one of the rooms. Safe. (a thin smile) I got us a table.
A WAITRESS delivers a pair of drinks to where Jonathan an Wyatt are seated.
Two Macallan 25 year. Enjoy. The Waitress leaves. Wyatt raises his glass.
To friendship. Jonathan just stares back at Wyatt.
Bansky's dead, isn't he? (CONTINUED)
He was dead when I met him. Just like you. The rest was a mere formality. (re: the laptop) Of course he didn't have your bargaining chip. Speaking of which...
Not until I see her. She's the only reason I'm here and not at the police.
I told you, she's in a room. Alive.
Give me the key then. Wyatt considers this, then takes out an electronic key ca and slides it across the table. Of course there's nothing the key card to indicate a room number.
As soon as you're done, I'll tell you the room number.
Not good enough. Wyatt reaches for the key card; as he does we glimpse a handgun concealed by his suit.
You won't let her live. You killed all the others, you'll have to kill us too.
Hey, I like you, okay? You'll be fine.
(scoffs, repulsed) You like me.
I do, Jonathan. In my way. After all, you're my creation. I'm the one who gave you life.
Don't you get it? It was her, not you! She's the one. She gave me life! You can steal my identity, but not what's here. (CONTINUED)
He puts his hand on his heart. Wyatt is startled by Jonathan's passionate outburst.
Yeah, well, I'm weeping big wet ones for you both. Now, let's get on with it. (BEAT)
I don't have all night, Jonathan. Jonathan reluctantly nods his assent. Wyatt lets go of th key card. Jonathan opens his bag...

CLOSE ON JONATHAN'S LAPTOP SCREEN as it defuzzes from sle The screen as it was, cursor blinking by the request for access code. Wyatt watches intensely as Jonathan starts to type -- the pauses, looking confused. Jonathan quickly reaches around. to the back of his lapto feels an empty jack - and suddenly turns pale.
What is it?
My wireless modem - I must have left it in the conference room. I can't get back online. Wyatt glares at Jonathan, seething.
You stupid fuck.
I can go back there and-
No. (thinks, then abruptly) Get up.
Wyatt and Jonathan crossing the lobby; they arrive at HOTEL GUEST BUSINESS CENTER, partitioned by a wall of gla Jonathan and Wyatt stand on the other side, peering in. (CONTINUED)
They don't let you use your own computer. Wyatt takes out a hundred dollar bill, gives it to Jonath
They will now. Jonathan takes the hundred, and heads into
Empty at this hour, with the exception of a sleepy-lookin EMPLOYEE. As Jonathan steps toward the desk, he takes out the hotel key card, his eyes travelling up to a clock overhead:

Wyatt eyes Jonathan on the other side of the glass. INSERT WYATT'S POV: Jonathan explaining himself to the cl Satisfied, Wyatt finds a comfortable chair with a direct of the business center's glass. Across the lobby, an attractive AUBURN-HAIRED WOMAN in business attire glances over at him.
Jonathan is subtly slipping the
You forgot your. own room number?
I just checked in and it's been a hectic day. Look at me! The Employee looks uneasy - something about the ill-conce tension in Jonathan's eyes.
You could just ask at the front desk. I'm sure they can-
I really don't have time, okay? Jonathan presses the bill into the Employee's palm, peers at the clock again: the big hand clicks over to 11:30. (CONTINUED)

head_text.subj: BACK TO WYATT IN THE LOBBY

text: Still eyeing Jonathan. He sees the Employee hesitate, the accept the money. Wyatt looks relieved -- when his view is abruptly blocked the Auburn-Haired Woman.
Pardon me, but may I ask you something - personal? Wyatt quickly looks up at her, momentarily confused.
Are you waiting for me?

head_text.subj: BACK TO JONATHAN IN BUSINESS CENTER

text: The Employee finishes swiping his card through a scanner.
Room 907.

head_text.subj: BACK TO WYATT IN THE LOBBY

text: His view of Jonathan still obscured by Auburn Hair.
What the hell are you -- And then he sees Auburn Hair glance unsurely at the Elois portrait, then at her cell phone's clock -- and now reali
Motherfucker! He jumps up, shoves Auburn Hair aside - eyes darting to t Business Center to find Jonathan no longer behind the gla just his laptop resting on the counter where he'd been standing.
Jonathan rushes into an elevator car just as it's about t close. He turns to find a YOUNG FAMILY riding up with him They've pressed floor 6. He presses floor

Wyatt arrives at the elevators - none are ready to open. furiously presses the call button, his hand hovering by h concealed gun. INT. Ding as the elevator doors open and the family step out. Jonathan is left alone, impatiently waiting for the doors close - - when his eyes land on something in the hallway: the fir alarm. He suddenly reaches out to stop the elevator door as it's about to close. INT. alarm blares to life. Pan an emergency exit stairwell.

Wyatt is just about to step onto an elevator, when a crow wedding guests also start to pile in. Furious, he abandon the elevators for the nearest stairs. INT. GUESTS spilling out of rooms met by the blaring alarm... INT. . as Jonathan smashes the glass of yet another fire alarm
Surveillance monitors show guests in the various hallways stairwells rushing in confusion at all angles...
We've got alarms on two - wait, three floors
Only the party 30 stories above remains oblivious: music still blasting, the upscale throngs still partying. 112.

Wyatt is bounding up the stairs, rounding the Fifth Floor - when he hears the door overhead bang open, and like a t wave a flood of guests fill the stairwell. Wyatt presses against the crush of bodies, pushing his wa the stairwell. INT. banged open by Jonathan's shoulder. The sound of the fire alarm is fainter up here as Jonatha races down the carpeted corridor, room numbers blurring p in sporadic fits Jonathan finally lurches to a halt before room 907. He takes out his key card, about to slide it in the slot when a hand grabs his forearm! He spins in panic to -- - a CLEANING WOMAN. She says something.in Vietnamese, indicating the ringing alarms.

Fire, I know - I'll be out in a minute. The scared Cleaning Woman nods and hurries off as Jonatha quickly slides the key in the slot. The light blinks gree He jerks the door handle and throws open the door to find

- nothing. The room is freshly made up, no sign of life o than A PORNO FILM BLARING from the TV set on Pay-Per-View Jonathan's heart is pounding - where is she? He searches every corner, the bathroom, the closets. Everywhere. The sterile room taunts him - the uncreased bedspread, th neat arrangement of the complimentary stationary, the incessant moaning coming from the porn on the TV set -- Jonathan suddenly erupts, grips the TV and shoves it off ledge. It hits the floor with a crash, and sudden silence Jonathan rubs his brow, heaving in desperation -- when hi eyes land on the sleek, dark piece on which the TV was (CONTINUED)

resting; it's a dense, rectangular block - only when Jona taps it, he realizes: it's hollow. He immediately seizes it, yanks it from the wall... And there she is, lying face down in a lifeless heap: "S" Panicked, Jonathan rushes to her, turns her over. She loo semi-conscious, hands and mouth duct-taped. Jonathan hurriedly removes the tape, gently shakes her, terrified how lifeless she appears - - when her eyes widen, focus on his face. Before he can s anything, she throws her arms around his neck, presses he face to his chest. azS., (whispers gratefully) You're alive. He's struck by these words, and nods, holding her face in hands as he kisses her urgently and gratefully.
What do you say we stick together from now on?
I'd like that.

A rush of guests hurriedly descending the staircase, a seemingly endless stream of densely packed faces. Close on Wyatt jostled within the flow of the wealthy gue as he's the only one heading up. He passes the 6th floor. INT. Jonathan and "S" hurrying down the hall - Jonathan torn between a choice of two stairwells. His eyes dart from on another

Wyatt forcing his way upstream with menacing determinatio his gaze is wilder, more and more irritated by the descen mob of successful, well-dressed guests he's pushing again - when he halts, peering up through the railings' lozenge shaped opening, past a collection of hands and profiles.. .to Jonathan and "S" some three stories above. (CONTINUED)

TIGHT ON WYATT. As yet unnoticed by Jonathan, he remains halted on a stair, bodies squeezing past him. TIGHTER ON HIS EYES. That predatory gleam. EVEN TIGHTER ON HIS GUN, tucked carefully at his side. CLOSE ON JONATHAN AND "S" three stories above, starting t descend -- when Jonathan notices the hint of disruption i flow of bodies below. Immediately wary, he leans over the railing, but can't ge good look. He grips the railing, leans further over... an his eyes find Wyatt's staring right back up at him --
He's down there! I saw him -
Oh God -

Up - we've got to go up! Clutching her arm, Jonathan and "S" turn back up, against flow of traffic. Stories above, less and less people are evacuating. ANGLE ON WYATT as he presses upward, his steely gaze even more rapacious. The crowd is thinning as Jonathan and "S" race upward as well. INSERT JONATHAN'S POV: a shaky, dizzying blur as they rac higher and higher... INSERT WYATT'S POV: from below but gaining on them, Jonat and "S". appearing and disappearing with each twist and t of the staircase... CLOSE ON JONATHAN AND "S", desperately racing upwards... CLOSE ON WYATT bounding the stairs, footsteps echoing, th staircase now empty and quiet, save for the footfall of Jonathan and "S" now... Wyatt slows his pace, leans into the railing, takes aim.. CLOSE ON JONATHAN AND "S" still hurrying up - when a shot rings out, a jolting echo clanging through the stairwell, (CONTINUED)

bullet missing them by inches. "S" screams, Jonathan tugs with him - when a second shot rings out, the bullet punching a den into the underside of the stairs just overhead. ON WYATT, realizing he needs a cleaner shot, taking the stairs even harder in pursuit, all merciless intensity.

The party is still at full throttle. Apparently no one ha yet told them of the alarms. CLOSE ON A STAIRWELL DOOR MARKED "EMERGENCY EXIT" as it suddenly bangs open and Jonathan and "S" spill out. They pause a moment - thrown by the sight of all the weal beautiful faces, laughing, dancing.

Come on! She grabs his hand, and they waste no time disappearing i the mass of bodies. They keep moving. Shoulder to shoulder within the swell o partiers, they fit right in - instantly anonymous not as smartly attired. BACK TO THE STAIRWELL DOOR as Wyatt enters the party, scanning the dense crowd, all senses alert. INSERT WYATT'S POV: just a mass of successful, attractive partying young men and women. There's no way to pick Jona and "S" out. Wyatt's smirk fades to an icy glare as he stalks the periphery. WITHIN THE CROWD "S" clutches Jonathan's hand, their head ducked low as they press forward... CLOSE ON WYATT, frustration gnashing at him as he quicken his pace, the idiotic enthusiasm of the crowd enraging hi sweat beading on his face -- when suddenly the music stops. Wyatt frowns., eyes dar CLOSE ON JONATHAN AND "S" glancing around in confusion -
Ladies and Gentlemen, we need everyone to evacuate the hotel. This way please. (CONTINUED)

The crowd noise resumes, as the throngs begrudgingly star for the exits. ON JONATHAN AND "S," doing their best to stay concealed within the exiting crowd. Angle on Wyatt pushing his way through the crush, shoving people aside, trying to find them - - when he suddenly stops. He has an idea. He takes out hi cell phone. BACK TO JONATHAN AND "5" within the crowd - - when Jonathan's cell phone RINGS. CLOSE ON JONATHAN as his eyes widen in panic. RING... He quickly fumbles for it, tries to turn it off - but it's too late... WHIP ACROSS THE CROWD to Wyatt, grinning wider. He's spotted them. In an instant he is be lining through the packed suits. WIDE SHOT OF THE ROOFTOP as the throngs are clearing out. Jonathan grabs "S" as they duck, racing across the dark, rooftop, looking for a place to hide. They take cover behind a large venting duct near the ledg gasping to catch their breath... Stepping back, "S's" foo clinks against something: a stray iron railing post. She reaches. down for it, starts to lift it - - when Wyatt's hand darts in and grasps the other end. She looks up in terror - when Wyatt punches her violently knocking her to the ground. Jonathan rushes to her - only to be blocked by Wyatt, gripping the iron rod tight.

Nice try back there, Jonathan. Looks like you picked up a thing or two from me. Jonathan tries to strike him - when with a lightning quic movement Wyatt whips the iron rod through the air, cracki Jonathan across the face.
Killer instinct, pall (CONTINUED)

Jonathan crumples, his glasses knocked to the ground. CLOSE ON WYATT as he grips the iron rod like a tennis racquet, steps into position - and brings the rod down on Jonathan with ruthless tenni strokes: Backhand! Bam! Forehand! Bam! Slice! Bam! Jonathan can barely peer up, bloody and beaten. He hears Wyatt drop the iron rod... JONATHAN'S POV: Wyatt's blurry figure hovering above sudd swoops in on us
- as Wyatt grabs Jonathan by the throat, hefts him up and yanks him back to the roof's concrete ledge. Jonathan fig to struggle free - when Wyatt jams the gun under his chin Jonathan freezes.
(GASPING)
They'll... catch... you...
Me? No - no, I'm just a face in the crowd. I'm a tourist, just passing through. JONATHAN'S POV: Wyatt's face presses closer, now almost i focus as he presses Jonathan's torso back over the ledge
As for you, you had your fun... Wyatt presses closer, crushing Jonathan's back to the edg
Now we're going to go back down... INSERT JONATHAN'S HAND reaching into Wyatt's pocket, his fingers fumbling for the cell phone
We're going to get that laptop... CLOSE ON JONATHAN'S FINGERS blindly prodding - he has the phone now - his fingers feel for the antenna...
And we're going to finish this, once and for - - when with all his strength Jonathan jams the cell phone into Wyatt's eye, the antenna punching into the retina. (CONTINUED)

Wyatt's grasp slips from Jonathan's collar as he stumbles back, cupping a hand to his wound as he swings his gun to Jonathan - - when with every ounce of strength Jonathan charges, Wya shot missing him as Jonathan slams him into the ledge wal seizing the momentum to turn himself - - as Wyatt falls right over the edge of the hotel rooftop
.Wyatt's body plummeting down the magnificent facade, vanishing into the vastness of the city below.

CLOSE ON JONATHAN as he crawls to the ledge, peers down i the darkness. He exhales, then turns back to "S" - to find she's right beside him, grateful tears in her e She leans into him, and he holds her tight, the two of th embraced on the precipice as we

Strobed reds and blues of police and fire.trucks amassed, trying to control the throngs of guests and pedestrians blocking our view of the body they're all gawking at. We travel through the confusion until we find JONATHAN AN "S" sitting side by side on the sidewalk curb, each propp against the other. The 'shock of it all is beginning to fade. He reaches int pocket and hands her 'Duck on Bike'.
Yours, I believe.
Thanks, Frank. She winds the toy up. They watch it make it's funny way d the sidewalk.
Can I ask you something personal? She nods. (CONTINUED)
What's your name? "S" considers the request, then smiles gently, leans in c and whispers the answer in his ear. Jonathan gazes at her moment - whatever her name is, it must be perfect.
So what now? She smiles up at him.
Well... are you free tonight? On Jonathan: treasuring these moments. He is truly free - perhaps for the first time in his life.
Yes. I'm free. They gaze at each other. We leave Jonathan and "S" to their privacy, pulling back they continue talking, continuing away until we're

head_text.subj: THROUGH A WINDOW AND INSIDE THE HOTEL ITSELF

text: the window itself now a frame, letter-boxing the scene, people passing like fish in their tank... except for Jona and S, seated center-frame, two small figures side by sid face to face, talking intimately as we. FADE OUT.
